The Supreme Court of Florida in discharging a writ of habeas corpus says that is correct.
If the warrant from the District of Columbia had been there, it wouldn't have been effective in Florida because it has no extraterritorial effect.
And unless it is under the extradition statutes, it would have no legal validity and no legal standing.
Now, I suggest to Your Honors that in view of the case dealing with this subject, will reveal that that is the situation so far as the cases are concerned throughout this country.
Now, it may be that there -- it maybe that it's necessary to make a change on that.
I don't know.
I'm almost persuaded from my learned friend on the other side that it is.
But I suggest to you that it can't be made within the framework of the Constitution by such a law as we have here, which is under consideration here.
Now --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But it could be accomplished?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think it could be accomplished?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, there is a statute, a federal statute, right now that aims in that same direction.
That's Section 1073, Title 18 of the U.S. Code which makes it a penal offense to depart from the jurisdiction to avoid testifying as a witness.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But that -- what is that statute?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Section 1073, Title 18 of the U.S. Code.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know but that -- that only means the witness arrived at in New York where --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- he was dragged from that apartment.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: That's true but it has, of course, its effect but certainly that is nothing.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it wouldn't -- wouldn't work here though --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Oh, it wouldn't work here.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) decided that in New York.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: No, it wouldn't work here.
No.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I suppose what you're suggesting is that if -- I -- I don't mean you're right but if there's any law at all passed that it have to by the Federal Government.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Yes, and in my judgment, it would have to be -- it would have to be pursuant to some constitutional authority.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But what's the constitutional authority that would support a federal statute at the time they were dealing with it here in Florida?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, unless Article -- unless Section 2 Article IV of the Constitution would authorize it, then that there is none.
Now, let me explain.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that one deals only with fugitives, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That deals only with --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Only with fugitives.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, then that -- that is what the situation.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: About the Commerce Clause?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: When you run to town under the Commerce Clause?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: What's that?
How about the Commerce Clause?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: As it's bearing on the subject that runs with it.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: You say there's no power of the Congress to act --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Oh, I see what you mean.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Why couldn't -- how could they -- could they act under the Commerce Clause?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, I frankly confess that I am not enough of a constitutional lawyer to answer that question.
I wish I could.
I just don't know it.

But I would say this, taking Innes against Tobin, which is one of the favorite cases of my esteemed contemporary, all of these cases that he has cited and all of these laws that he has referred to have one thing in common.
All of them are in aid of interstate rendition of fugitives from justice, all of them.

Even the Uniform Act dealing with deserters who desert their families because in Florida and many States, it is a felony to desert a person, wife or children, and so even that is in aid of the federal power.
It may be that a statute which would authorize the interstate institution of witnesses, passed by Congress, would be likewise held to be in aid of the power to extradite fugitives from justice.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I have trouble with that, frankly.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Frankly, I do too, Mr. Justice Brennan.

And if it doesn't -- if that isn't the solution, then I don't think there is any constitutional solution short of the amendment to the Section 2 of Article IV to provide for the interstate extradition witness.
I'm frank to say I agree with you on that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Cushman --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: I have trouble with it too.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- are you familiar with the case of Blackmer against the United States?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Isn't that the one where he was brought from another country?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's where an American citizen living in Paris --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- refused to heed a subpoena to appear as a witness in one of the courts to the district or in New York.
Now, what bearing do you think if any, does in that case has upon this situation, except that there we were dealing with the -- there, the legislation, we're dealing with an American citizen.

But there was a person who was living in Paris insofar as a mean -- physical means of hauling him out of Paris, they were beyond the power of this country, of this Government to recall just as a sheriff you say, his power will evaporate as soon he reaches the border of Florida, so the power of any American official evaporates except by -- by leave of the foreign country.

It has no power that this country can give him and yet this Court sustained a statute which said, "If he doesn't turn up, he shall be found in absentia, guilty of contempt subject to a fine of $100,000 and the forfeiture and the seizure of his property to -- to pay, to liquidate that $100,000.
Now, I've -- I've indicated that's with a citizen.

And therefore, if we have the case of a Floridian citizen or if this man that Illinois had this statute and you haven't -- not heeding New York request, default and with relation to Illinois who gives that this is lack of motive to the United States.
What do you say to that case?
Has that any bearing at all on you?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: I do not consider it has any bearing on the case that we have before the Court today.
Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because as far as due process is concerned, what kind of safeguard were protected there, that are not protected here?
Because I think privileges, immunity or unequal protection is not for privileges, immunities and for myself I don't mind saying I think there's nothing in it because there is no discrimination.
Everybody gets the same deal, a Floridian citizen has indeed seen the difference with the others but I mean to see the difference in many other citizens.

Do you think the Blackmer case has no bearing after the egression of power over just the human beings who are freed from the possible physical control which is the ultimate power of sovereignty and yet he was subjected to a condemnation of contempt and the seizure of property worth $100,000 and all the stigmas as mentioned.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, I don't think it does because that I think that the power of the States is quite different than the power of the Federal Government.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Certainly it is but as to the people that are within it, and -- and constitutionally speaking, if a fellow wants to take advantage of sunshine and all the other favoring circumstances of life in Florida, then to that extent, Florida has some control over him.

And it -- it could be a response to the kind of things that is not without justification and -- and I have to press you insofar as due process is concerned by seizing somebody whom you had no control except within your limits of what greater -- what greater protection was there in Blackmer than there is here in saying, “You're within our State, you enjoy the benefits of it.

We have an agreement with the State of New York to our advantage in a cause that is morally a right and indeed had to be essential to the safety of a society in which you respond to the subpoena in court.”

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, Your Honor certainly makes a convincing presentation of the subject.
I could not deny that.
I merely suggest to Your Honor that the States of the Union don't possess that power, and while Your Honor's argument -- I don't feel that I should surrender the point, if I may.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does the record show where this man lived?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Yes, sir.
The record shows that Mr. O'Neill was a resident and citizen of the State of Illinois.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does the record show anything about his being in New York?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: No, sir.
It does not.
And I'm glad you mentioned that because I'd like to say a word about it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What -- what does the record show about that?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: The record doesn't show --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That would be -- that would be material if you were a fugitive from justice.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What does the record show about that here?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: The record doesn't show whether he was ever in New York or whether he was in New York a week before the District Attorney started the proceedings in New York.
It merely says that they had tried without success to get him to appear as a witness.
Now, it isn't stated that they ever had a witness subpoena issued for him in New York and tried to serve him but couldn't serve him.
We never -- it isn't stated that they had a witness subpoena served.
If they did issued and if it did serve it and he refused to respond to it or anything of the sort.
It doesn't even say that they ever personally asked him to come and that he directly refused.
They simply say they haven't been able to get him there.
Now, that's all there is in the record on the subject.
Does that answer Your Honor's question?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That -- it's probably not material to the narrow contrast of the points you are raising.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, I think it's -- I think it's material in this respect if I may.

I think it's material because this application that the people of the State of New York from this proceeding was originally begun, didn't contain any kind of facts which would support any sort of a seizure of a person.

Now, I contend -- it is my contention that in order to sustain the issuance of process of a drastic nature such as the seizure of a person, that there should be facts stated to support the application.
Just like if you go to apply for an injunction, you've got to state the facts upon which to show the necessity for the issuance of the injunction.

And if it's necessary to state facts in order to support an application for an injunction, certainly, it ought to be necessary to state facts to authorize an application for the seizure of a person in a distant State and transportation back, if you please, as a prisoner.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well I suppose, I -- I'm just asking, because I don't know.

Suppose you lose this case here on the judgment as it is, do you mean that he would be cut-off from going into the courts of Florida to show, for instance, if he could, that he has never been in New York?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Could -- would there be anything left to try or would -- is it -- would it -- on -- on your viewpoint, would it mean that all you have to do is to give notice from one State once a man is a witness and he has to go, just on then?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, rightly or wrongly, the learned circuit judge said that he did not consider that any testimony was -- could be offered on the subject.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was there an offer --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: And it had to be decided on the face of the application.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was there an offer made to present a testimony?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, I want to present some testimony but he wouldn't hear anything, and the District Attorney from New York wanted to make some statements about what was said to the judge at the time the application was made in New York State and the circuit judge in Florida refused likewise to hear that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, do you consider this -- that would be foreclosed if the -- if the Court should decide against you and hold that the law is balanced?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Under the decision as it now stands, it seems to me that the only thing that the Court would be willing to hear me on would be on the question of whether there is some peculiar reason which would make any hardship on O'Neill to go to New York State.
That's, as a witness, and that's about the only thing I believe the Court would entertain any kind of a hearing on.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well now, the statute as reproduced in the appendix to your brief on Page 30, 942.02 Section 2 provides that -- provides for a hearing in Florida, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And for a determination after a hearing that the witness is material and necessary that it will not cause undue hardship to the witness to be compelled to attend and testify and also that he will be immune from service while he's there.
Is that the price?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, that's correct.
That's exactly what it provides.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And you -- you of course never had a hearing in this case because the circuit judge decided you will ride on your constitutional claim and that was affirmed by the Supreme Court of Florida.
If -- if perchance this Court should disagree with that, then you go back and have the right to this kind of a hearing, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Yes, but to be frank with, Your Honor, I don't know what we would contend, for example, whether he would served his due process in New York or in any State to which he might go, does appear to me that he -- largely a question of law than it is a question of facts.
And the only other question that it would appear to me, it would be open for a consideration and discussion could be where it would constitute a hardship for him to go to New York.

And I suggest that to go to New York as a prisoner in custody of an officer and my examinations in New York decisions indicate that in this lack of investigation, the practice has been almost uniform for a bond around $200,000 or the -- the witness be in jail.
Now, in my brief filed with the Supreme of Court of Florida, I had adverted to that subject.

And of course I can very well see how he might get to New York when we say, "Well, Mr. O'Neill, we'll be glad to issue a bond higher while you're here, if you want to post a bond, say $200,000 that Mr. O'Neill couldn't post a bond of $200,000, they'd say well to the two with it, and when we get ready for him as a witness, we'll call him as a witness if you know right where he is.
That's the situation (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: May I ask you, sir.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is Mr. O'Neill still under bond to the Dade County Court or not?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: To be frank about it, I can only say this.
The order of the circuit judge which was to discharge him, discharge him and ensure he's on a bond.

Now, it may well be, it may well be that if this Court should reverse its decision with the Supreme Court of Florida and so by operation of law reverse the decision of the circuit judges that he would be held, in all likelihood, that the discharge of the bonds would be in effect with and the bonds wouldn't be required to produce, Mr. O'Neill before the judge --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, wouldn't -- wouldn't reversal of the judgment of the Supreme Court of Florida have the effect of vacating the order of the circuit judge dismissing the bond?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: I don't think there's any question about it.
I'm in agreement with you, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, I didn't intend to indicate.
I'm just asking.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: I think you're right.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, if that's true, do we have -- if the bond has been discharged, do we have only a moot case here now?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, that's something --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Mr. Justice Whittaker, you have touched the point which I considered and the reason I did not argue that point in the Supreme Court of Florida.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, I might have argued.
I thought, at least I considered arguing whether -- since O'Neill is back in Illinois and the bond has been discharged whether it would be a moot question or not.
But I didn't argue it because I didn't think that it was an argument that I should make.
And it's not too much of an argument to the effect that O'Neill would defy the law or the lies his attorney would advise him to and I didn't make the argument.
And I can only give you the same answer here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The only way they can get it back from New York (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: I think you're correct, Mr. Justice Black.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Frankly, I know of none.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, if the bond is not gone.
As far as that's concerned, the bonds would simply lose the forfeiture and that's that.
He still wouldn't be able to get it because there would still be no basis for forcing him to return.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: That's correct.
And of course if the bond --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It still remains that he's not in Florida.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It still remains that he's not in Florida.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, that is correct.
That's right.
And so if the bonds couldn't induce him to return to Florida, it might be that the bond -- this feature of the bond would be the only remedy left.
Now, there's no use to dissemble on that point.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, frankly, I doubt it, Mr. Justice Black.
But I --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But he still (Inaudible) of any crime.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: No, sir.
He's not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There's no way to extradite him for a crime.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: He could not --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He couldn't be indicted (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: No, you couldn't have indicted him.
No, sir.
No way to indict.
If Your Honors please, I thank you for your --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about -- what about the grand jury, the New York grand jury?
Do you know whether it's still in session?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: My understanding is that it is not in session.
Now, whether the State of New York really wants O'Neill at this time, I cannot tell you.
I did write to the District Attorney of New York County and asked him if he was any longer interested in Mr. O'Neill.
He wrote me back and said in substance or effect that they are always interested in Mr. O'Neill.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you say about the grand jury was given session that there's something that (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: He did not but I knew that it had been discharged because it was in November grand jury and it had continued over until spring of the following year, and I knew that it was discharged.
But of course I suppose that he intended to inform me that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: -- another grand jury might like to see him anyway.
So that is that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is this the only inference that has arisen in Florida, so far as -- so far as know under the Uniform Act?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: As far as I know, this is the only decision that has ever reached the courts and certainly this is the only decision on this subject which has ever reached the court of last resort of any State.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But the -- the statute itself has been used in other cases at that time.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Yes, sir.
And in the record, you will find as an appendix to the opinion of the nisi prius judge and listed the 13 or 14 cases in which this Act has been construed in one way or another.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, I didn't mean that.
I mean, Florida they have another application than this one, have they not?
Has it -- for -- to take witnesses of the State?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: I am sure there have been but I don't know about it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This is an active statute, isn't it?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: I expect that it is.
Yes, sir.
I don't doubt it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You say as a former state trial judge is in my State if there's some jury.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible) many orders under this -- this kind of statute.
It was very wrong without ever having anyone suggest that you successfully (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well, In re Stamer, I believe, was one of those cases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That came after I think.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: At any rate, if Your Honors please, I have no doubt that it is a statute which has had considerable use and perhaps it has some value.
But I say, nevertheless, that there are not many who might be called as witnesses, who would have the means to make the defense which Mr. O'Neill has made in this case.
And I respectfully suggest that there may be many who have suffered the rigors of this statute without being able to complain effectively about it.
If --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I assure you, this is my last question.

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: That's all right, as --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: -- many as you like.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- but there is, maybe, some misunderstanding as to your answer to my question that followed.
The bond, under which Mr. O'Neill was released by the Circuit Court of Dade County, is or is not yet effective?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Can you give us the facts and your conclusion briefly?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: I can indeed.
When Mr. O'Neill came to Florida to preside at a meeting of the International Union, he was seized on an attachment, a body attachment.
He was taken immediately before the circuit judge.

The circuit judge ordered him released upon giving a bond, condition that he would appear at any subsequent hearing in the proceedings and stand to and abide by any order that the court made in the premise.
When the time came, he being at liberty on the bond, I filed a response and motion, to quash the attachment and the rule to show cause.
And the Court, in an opinion and ordered, granted my motion and discharged the rule to show cause and the attachment and discharged the bond and discharged O'Neill and his sureties on that bond.

Now, then, I suspect, and I will state that it is my opinion, based on those facts, that if the judgment of the Circuit Court is reversed, it would necessarily reverse also the order discharging the bond so that the bond would still be in effect.
Yes, sir?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And you don't consider this case moot?

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: To the extent that the bond is involved?
No, sir.
As far as actually getting O'Neill back to Florida, it might well be considered moot.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: l_j_cushman
turn.label: Mr. L. J. Cushman
turn.text: The bond is made payable to -- as I can recall it to the Governor of the State of Florida and his successors in office.
It's an ordinary bail bond.
And a suit would have to be maintained by the State for the benefit of the fine and forfeiture fund is my opinion.
It isn't anything that would operate to the financial benefit of the people in the State of New York, however much that might be desired.
Thank you, gentlemen.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Bowen.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Yes, sir.
May it please the Court.
I don't think the case is moot.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: I said I don't think this case is moot because if this Court -- Court of the State of Florida has swung in the balance the question of whether it can collect that bond or not.
If the decision is reversed, then -- and Mr. O'Neill doesn't show up whenever -- when he's demanded, then the bond will be mistreated and if he doesn't show up, it can be collected.

But if the Court should dismiss the case as being moot, then Florida is automatically cutoff from collecting that bond because it would leave in effect the order of the Circuit Court and affirmed by the Supreme Court saying they have no right to -- to do anything to him at all.
We'd -- we'd lose the right to collect the bond we are entitled have.
If this thing is reversed, we're entitled to have him or the bond money.
And -- and a dismissal would cut us off from the possibility of getting either one.
It's always possible that a man will get to feel like he -- he's small enough to slip in and out of state and try -- and -- and have another dash down, then they'd catch him again.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What was the amount of the bond?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: I don't remember, sir.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Now, let me say this.
Some question was raised about what could be heard if this thing is reversed.
The question can be heard under the law as to whether Mr. O'Neill is a material and necessary witness because our statute requires the judge to determine that fact.

And if Mr. O'Neill is able to show our judge down there that he is not a material witness in spite all these positions that he holds in the union, the head of all or most everything in it, and in spite of that, he knows nothing about the -- the facts that the grand jury is trying to investigate up there.
Then if the judge finds that to be true, he will necessarily find that he's not a necessary witness and he won't -- he -- he can't under the law, hold him to set up.
I think that question is certainly open for consideration if this case should be reversed.
Now, Mr. Cushman still contends --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: I do not, I'm sorry.
I have him --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: It was, sir.
It was.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But suppose the grand jury (Inaudible) what would you say?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Well, they -- they have -- if they don't have that, well, I'm sure they've got a successor grand jury.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I understand that but (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: He hasn't been summoned to appear before any grand jury so far.
In other words, no action has been taken to require him to go before any grand jury.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: We originally have a case, isn't it?
That question came up (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Yes, sir, but -- now, if a subpoena --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It means whether or not the grand jury (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: If a subpoena has been issued to him back then in 1956 when this case was decided in the Circuit Court, and if -- while the case was on appeal to the Supreme Court of Florida, it had made -- made to appear that the body before whom the subpoena was returnable, that is the grand jury, had ceased to exist.
Then, the hauling would have to have been in his favor as to that particular subpoena, but here we've had no subpoena at all.
And I don't know actually whether the same grand jury has been in session or not.
I -- some of these grand juries last a long time but I don't know about that one.

But even so, it says no subpoena has been issued which could have been vitiated by the -- by the expiration of that grand jury term and says New York still wants him before a grand jury and a subpoena could be issued to put him before a current grand jury.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You say no subpoena has been issued.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: No -- no subpoena has ever been issued.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How did Florida directly involve there?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: They have not.
He -- he'd be --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And what -- what was the basis on which it asked that he'd be sent (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: The basis of course, New York asked that he'd be sent there once if they'll go have a term of grand jury and they already had one, I believe, in session, that they were investigating the disposition of funds in the union, certain unions including Mr. O'Neill's union.
And that was the basis upon which they asked for him to come.
They wanted his testimony before the grand jury.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And I can see it on the basis (Inaudible) the witness before the said grand jury be required to appear 15 days.

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think that the judgment would be just to go ahead on this same case or some other grand juries?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: I hadn't considered that but I -- I think that -- that it says New York still wants him before a grand jury.
That it's utterly immaterial whether they put him before that grand jury that was in session in 1956 or whether they put him before a new -- new grand jury.

They -- I -- I couldn't state a fact that more adequately attest to the fact that New York wants him than to point out all the expense and effort it has made to get this case heard here in this Court to get -- to -- to get it reversed so they could get.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So in any event, Mr. Bowen, there's never been an actual hearing in any of the three elements that Justice Stewart referred to in the statute, has there, and since the --

turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: There has been -- there has been no hearing on the facts at all.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, now, if you should prevail on the constitutional question that there'd have to be a hearing, is it not?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: It would -- it would -- the -- the person is entitled to a hearing (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And it might be that -- it might be that the fact finding now would be that one or more of those requisites could not be satisfied.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: It is possible that the -- that the hearing would so develop.
He might be able to produce proof that it would show that and he would -- should not be said under that law.
But that has not been determined.
It's -- it's solely on the face of the papers that the decision of the Circuit Court was rendered.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Bowen, I have another question.
It's been covered, I've missed it.
It suggested in the briefs that another infirmity of this legislation may be that it does not provide for release on bail (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Our Supreme Court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, I know in this case the man was released and that may be the answer --

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: And that's --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- that that's their (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: But -- but the bail that -- that Mr. Cushman had in mind as I understood it was to put him on bail to go to New York, not temporary bail pending a hearing in the Florida Court.
But given with -- now, Pennsylvania for example has got a statute which says that a man that sought to be extradited can make bail to appear there unless it's a capital case I believe.
I think that I ran across that -- that statement in -- in a case cited by Mr. Cushman In re Allen.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that is all -- all the courts unless it has explicitly prohibited power to allow people on bail and free them from incarceration.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: No, sir, you can't when it comes to extradition.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) extradition, as to the crime --

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: For crime --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- for detention of witnesses?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Our Constitution provides that -- that he is entitled to bail unless he's charged with a capital offense in serious circumstances.
He -- he is entitled to bail --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) witnesses, not a -- a potential criminal (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Sir --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You have to begin with exact legislation dealing with the procuring of testimony from witnesses and not the process of conviction for crime.(Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: That -- that's what we're dealing with.
We're not dealing with a conviction for crime at all.
In fact, there's no crime charged against Mr. O'Neill, first or last.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, do you think that the statute does provide for enlargement on bail?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: You mean to the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Pending a hearing, say or --

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Pending hearing in Florida?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: I -- I impliedly conceded to that without -- by never raising it in the Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And I suppose that's the short answer that it's not therefore before us.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: I -- I just -- I just accepted that it was fitting and proper and it was in the Court's power to do it.

Where he felt like the fellow wouldn't run off but would respond to the bond, and his faithful justified in this instance because he did respond, and to hear it, until he was discharged by order of the Court.
In this --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was the order -- was the order issued to him to go back?

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: No, he was ordered to go back.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But was the judgment of the court based solely on the order of judge -- the --

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Circuit judge?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No, the judge in New York as shown by the order that he was just here before November grand jury of that year.
Is that the only basis on which the order rests and on which the controversy with him as to going back (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: That has, to my knowledge, been nothing put before the Florida court except that original certificate of Judge Fischer, the New York judge.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And that's what Judge Holt acted on.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: That is what he acted on and -- and among other things, he held that the papers on their face didn't show that Mr. O'Neill was a material and necessary witness but Supreme Court of Florida turned him down on that and said that was -- and they said they did show on its face.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And the Supreme Court of Florida did not test below under his own constitution, did it, but reserved that --

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: No --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- reserved that for the future.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: I -- I don't recall a single reference to the Constitution of Florida in the decision.
I don't think there is any.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I -- I thought I read one a moment ago.
Maybe, I didn't.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Well, perhaps you did but I don't recall it.
It may -- it may have been a reference to due process.
It may have been Section maybe 12, the Declaration of Rights and the Fourteenth Amendment afford due process.
But -- but they didn't place their decision on that.
They placed their decision squarely upon the two sources of the Federal Constitution.
In spite of this, Mr. Cushman continues to argue that the sole power of extradition --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Solicitor General, I think our -- our time for adjournment and your time is up.
I think we'll have to -- we'll have to take an adjournment now, and we'll get the rest from your brief.

turn.speaker: reeves_bowen
turn.label: Mr. Reeves Bowen
turn.text: Thank you.
